title: 105_hr1325
content: The State Administrator shall establish a Problem Resolution Office with officers authorized to investigate taxpayer complaints and halt collection activities if deemed non-compliant with the law. The highest official in the relevant taxing authority can reverse the injunction only with clear evidence. Officers cannot be penalized unless a pattern of unreasonable injunctions is proven. This does not limit legal remedies in court. The Secretary will establish an Office of Revenue Allocation to resolve disputes among states regarding the destination of taxable property for revenue allocation. The destination of tangible personal property is determined by the state where it was first delivered to the purchaser. The destination of tangible personal property is determined by the state where it was first delivered to the purchaser. Tangible personal property shipped by mail or common carrier is deemed delivered to the purchaser's location upon shipment. Real property's destination is the state where it is located, while other property's destination is the purchaser's residence. Services' destination is the state where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed, with telecommunications services being the residence of the purchaser. The destination of transportation services within the United States is the final destination of the trip, while for international transportation services, 50 percent of the service amount is attributed to the United States. Financial intermediation services are determined by the residence of the purchaser. State Tax Administrators have jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within their state. The jurisdiction of State Tax Administrators extends to gross payments within their state, including rents and royalties for tangible property leases. The destination of such payments is determined by the location of the property or the residence of the lessee for vehicles. SEC. 54. Tax to be stated and charged separately. For each purchase of taxable property or services subject to a sales tax, the vendor must separately charge the tax from the purchase price and provide a receipt to the purchaser. The receipt should include details such as the price before tax, amount of tax paid, total price including tax, tax rate, date of sale, vendor's name, and registration number. However, sales made through vending machines are exempt from these requirements. Vending machines must dispense taxable property for coins or bills up to twenty dollars and cannot sell items over ten dollars each. The State Administrator or Secretary can enter installment agreements with taxpayers to facilitate tax collection. The agreement remains valid unless inaccurate information is provided. They can also compromise on amounts due. Vendors must use the cash method for tax remittance, but can elect the accrual method for invoiced sales. SEC. 57 of the tax code states that the exemption for hobby activities is not available if the trade or business is not for profit. If gross payments exceed certain expenses in 2 of the last 4 years, the business is deemed for profit. The tax code prohibits appropriations for certain IRS expenses, establishes Excise Tax and Sales Tax Bureaus, and allows the appointment of up to 5 Assistant General Counsels by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Treasury can appoint up to 5 Assistant General Counsels without following civil service laws. Tax rates for taxable years ending June 30, 1999, will be modified for both calendar year and fiscal year taxpayers. The Secretary will publish tax rate schedules accordingly. The Social Security Administration will collect payroll taxes starting January 1, 1999. Section 7 of the Act covers self-employment tax rules. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define 'self-employment income' as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus certain expenses and deductions. Transition amounts for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 are calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount of prior law section 167 property placed in service before January 1, 1999. The remaining income tax basis pertains to prior law section 167 property placed in service before January 1, 1999, and inventory held at the end of 1998. Conforming amendments repeal subsections 1402(b) and 1402(c), while renumbering subsections 1402(d) et seq. as subsections 1402(b) et seq. SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS INDEXED ON SALES TAX INCLUSIVE BASIS. The Consumer Price Index for Social Security benefits is amended to include the national sales tax paid. The Consumer Price Index for Social Security benefits is adjusted to include the national sales tax factor, which is calculated based on the difference between the current quarter's CPI and the previous base quarter's CPI, taking into account the national sales tax rate. SEC. 9. COMPENSATING PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN PERSONS ON FIXED INCOME. Compensating Payment: Eligible persons receive a compensating payment if they comply with the application requirements. The payment is calculated based on the qualified fixed income payment amount and the excess inflation rate. An eligible person is someone who receives Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments. Qualified fixed income payments are received from defined benefit plans or annuity contracts. An eligible person can receive compensating payments based on qualified fixed income payments from defined benefit plans or annuity contracts. The qualified fixed income payment amount is determined as \1/12\ of the total payments an eligible person is entitled to receive in the following year, capped at $5,000. Payments that vary with investment performance, interest rates, or inflation are not considered qualified fixed income payments. The excess inflation rate is defined as the difference between the consumer price index during a specific period and the projected increase. To receive compensating payments, eligible individuals must apply as required and will receive the payment with their Social Security benefit. The funds for compensating payments will come from the general fund. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may require insurers and defined benefit plan sponsors to issue a statement to annuitants or plan participants for qualified fixed income payment amounts. The compensating payment for security benefits will come from the general fund. SEC. 10 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to lower the interest rate. SEC. 11 requires a supermajority vote in Congress to raise federal sales tax rates or provide tax benefits that reduce federal revenues.
